channel.title: Comments on: SQL Server Licensing for Non-Production
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Mike Kerns
item.dc:creator: Mike Kerns
item.description: Sorry to raise a zombie thread but this is somewhat relevant. With mergers and acquisitions, if an acquisistion had an EA with SQL Server and SA, but let the EA expire, does the SQL server in the DEV/Test environment now need to be licensed?
item.content:encoded: Sorry to raise a zombie thread but this is somewhat relevant. With mergers and acquisitions, if an acquisistion had an EA with SQL Server and SA, but let the EA expire, does the SQL server in the DEV/Test environment now need to be licensed?

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.description: haha! where's the like button for Denis's comment :D
item.content:encoded: haha! where’s the like button for Denis’s comment ðŸ˜€

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: Don't most companies test in production only, they just slap a beta tag on the site :-)
item.content:encoded: Don’t most companies test in production only, they just slap a beta tag on the site ðŸ™‚

item.title: By: Kevin Conan
item.dc:creator: Kevin Conan
item.content:encoded:
Correct!

But if you have people who do not have MSDN Subscriptions testing against these SQL Instances, you need either MSDN License or SQL Developer Edition Licenses or Enterprise Agreement to cover them.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: I believe if the developers have a MSDN license, the don't need a separate license for the developer instance either
item.content:encoded: I believe if the developers have a MSDN license, the don’t need a separate license for the developer instance either
